trans-unit.source: Extends the design mode behavior of a <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control"></xref>.
<xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.ControlDesigner> provides a base class for designers of components that derive from <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control>.

In addition to the methods and functionality inherited from the <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.ComponentDesigner> class, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.ControlDesigner> provides additional methods to support extending and altering the behavior of an associated <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control> at design time.
You can associate a designer with a type using a <xref:System.ComponentModel.DesignerAttribute>.
For an overview of customizing design time behavior, see [Extending Design-Time Support](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/d6ac8a6a-42fd-4bc8-bf33-b212811297e2).
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.ControlDesigner"></xref> class.
Specifies the accessibility object for the designer.
The default value is `null`.
Gets the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleObject"></xref> assigned to the control.
For more information about accessible objects, see the Active Accessibility section of the MSDN Library.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleObject"></xref> assigned to the control.
Gets the collection of components associated with the component managed by the designer.
This property indicates any components to copy or move along with the component managed by the designer during a copy, drag, or move operation.

If this collection contains references to other components in the current design mode document, those components will be copied along with the component managed by the designer during a copy operation.
When the component managed by the designer is selected, this collection is filled with any nested controls.
This collection can also include other components, such as the buttons of a toolbar.
The components that are associated with the component managed by the designer.
Gets or sets a value indicating whether resize handle allocation depends on the value of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control.AutoSize"></xref> property.
`true` if resize handle allocation depends on the value of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control.AutoSize"></xref> and `AutoSizeMode` properties; otherwise, `false`.
The default is `false`.
Processes Windows messages.
This method causes the message to be processed by Windows, skipping the control.
This is useful if you want to block the message from getting to the control, but you do not want to block it from getting to Windows itself because it can cause other messages to be generated.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Message"></xref> to process.
Gets the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService"></xref> from the design environment.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.BehaviorService"></xref>, or `null` if the service is unavailable.
Indicates if this designer's control can be parented by the control of the specified designer.
This method is useful for testing whether a control can be parented by a particular type of parent.
For example, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TabPage> controls can only be parented by <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TabControl> controls.
This method is not called when an item is dragged from the **Toolbox** onto the design surface.
The <xref href="System.ComponentModel.Design.IDesigner"></xref> that manages the control to check.
`true` if the control managed by the specified designer can parent the control managed by this designer; otherwise, `false`.
Gets the control that the designer is designing.
The control that the designer is designing.
Provides default processing for Windows messages.
This method causes the message to be processed by the control, rather than by the designer.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Message"></xref> to process.
Displays information about the specified exception to the user.
The <xref href="System.Exception"></xref> to display.
Releases the unmanaged resources used by the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.ControlDesigner"></xref> and optionally releases the managed resources.
This method is called by the public `Dispose()` method and the <xref:System.Object.Finalize%2A> method.
`Dispose()` invokes the protected `Dispose(Boolean)` method with the `disposing` parameter set to `true`.
<xref:System.Object.Finalize%2A> invokes `Dispose` with `disposing` set to `false`.
When the `disposing` parameter is `true`, this method releases all resources held by any managed objects that this <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.ControlDesigner> references.
This method invokes the `Dispose()` method of each referenced object.
`true` to release both managed and unmanaged resources; `false` to release only unmanaged resources.
Enables design time functionality for a child control.
The child control specified by `child` is a child of this control designer's control.
The child does not directly participate in persistence, but it will if it is exposed as a property of the main control.
Consider a control like the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.SplitContainer>: it has two panels, `Panel1` and `Panel2`.

These panels are exposed through read only <xref:System.Windows.Forms.SplitContainer.Panel1%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.SplitContainer.Panel2%2A> properties on the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.SplitContainer> control.

The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.SplitContainer> control's designer calls <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.ControlDesigner.EnableDesignMode%2A> for each panel, which allows other components to be dropped on them.

But, in order for the contents of <xref:System.Windows.Forms.SplitContainer.Panel1%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.SplitContainer.Panel2%2A> to be saved, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.SplitContainer> control itself must expose the panels as public properties.
Control names must be unique within a control designer, but they are not required to be unique with respect to the children of other control designers.
To support this feature, the hosting infrastructure must expose the <xref:System.ComponentModel.INestedContainer> class as a service through the site.
The child control for which design mode will be enabled.
The name of child as exposed to the end user.
`true` if the child control could be enabled for design time; `false` if the hosting infrastructure does not support it.
child or name is `null`.
Enables or disables drag-and-drop support for the control being designed.
The default value of `false` specifies that a control cannot have children dragged onto it at design time.
To allow a control to parent other controls at design time, associate it with a designer that derives from <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.ParentControlDesigner>.
`true` to enable drag-and-drop support for the control; `false` if the control should not have drag-and-drop support.
The default is `false`.
Gets a value indicating whether drag rectangles can be drawn on this designer component.
`true` if drag rectangles can be drawn; otherwise, `false`.
Returns a <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.ControlBodyGlyph"></xref> representing the bounds of this control.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.GlyphSelectionType"></xref> value that specifies the selection state.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.ControlBodyGlyph"></xref> representing the bounds of this control.
Gets a collection of <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Glyph"></xref> objects representing the selection borders and grab handles for a standard control.
Note that based on `selectionType`, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Glyph> objects returned will represent one of these selection states:
A fully resizable selection border with grab handles;
A locked selection border;
A single 'hidden' selection <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Glyph>.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.GlyphSelectionType"></xref> value that specifies the selection state.
A collection of <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.Glyph"></xref> objects.
Indicates whether a mouse click at the specified point should be handled by the control.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.ControlDesigner.GetHitTest%2A> method determines whether a click at the specified point should be passed to the control, while the control is in design mode.
You can override and implement this method to enable your control to receive clicks in the design-time environment.

You can pass a point in screen coordinates to the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.PointToClient%2A> method of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control> class to obtain the coordinates of the point relative to the upper-left corner of the control.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.ControlDesigner.GetHitTest%2A> method is called in response to the WM_NCHITTEST message, so it is called on each mouse move.
A <xref href="System.Drawing.Point"></xref> indicating the position at which the mouse was clicked, in screen coordinates.
`true` if a click at the specified point is to be handled by the control; otherwise, `false`.
Routes messages from the child controls of the specified control to the designer.
The first child <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control"></xref> to process.
This method may recursively call itself for children of the control.
Gets the <xref href="System.ComponentModel.InheritanceAttribute"></xref> of the designer.

<xref href="System.ComponentModel.InheritanceAttribute.Inherited"></xref> if the designer is a root designer; otherwise, the value of the parent designer's <xref href="System.ComponentModel.Design.ComponentDesigner.InheritanceAttribute"></xref> property.
Initializes the designer with the specified component.
This method is called by the designer host to initialize the designer.
The <xref href="System.ComponentModel.IComponent"></xref> to associate the designer with.
This component must always be an instance of, or derive from, <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control"></xref>.
Re-initializes an existing component.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.ControlDesigner> class overrides this method to handle after-drop cases.
A name/value dictionary of default values to apply to properties.
May be `null` if no default values are specified.
Initializes a newly created component.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.ControlDesigner> class overrides this method.
It will look at the default property for the control and, if it is of type `string`, it will set this property's value to the name of the component.
It only does this if the designer has been configured with this option in the options service.
This method also connects the control to its parent and positions it.
If you override this method, you should always call base.
A name/value dictionary of default values to apply to properties.
May be `null` if no default values are specified.
Returns the internal control designer with the specified index in the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.ControlDesigner"></xref>.
An internal control is a control that is not in the <xref:System.ComponentModel.IContainer.Components%2A> collection of the <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.IDesignerHost.Container%2A>.
<xref:System.Windows.Forms.SplitterPanel> is an example of one such control.
A specified index to select the internal control designer.
This index is zero-based.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.ControlDesigner"></xref> at the specified index.
Defines a local <xref href="System.Drawing.Point"></xref> that represents the values of an invalid <xref href="System.Drawing.Point"></xref>.

<xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.ControlDesigner.InvalidPoint> has an <xref:System.Drawing.Point.X%2A> and <xref:System.Drawing.Point.Y%2A> property set to the minimum value for the integer data type.
Returns the number of internal control designers in the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.ControlDesigner"></xref>.
An internal control is a control that is not in the <xref:System.ComponentModel.IContainer.Components%2A> collection of the <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.IDesignerHost.Container%2A>.
<xref:System.Windows.Forms.SplitterPanel> is an example of one such control.
The number of internal control designers in the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.ControlDesigner"></xref>.
Shows the context menu and provides an opportunity to perform additional processing when the context menu is about to be displayed.
The x coordinate at which to display the context menu.
The y coordinate at which to display the context menu.
Provides an opportunity to perform additional processing immediately after the control handle has been created.
Receives a call to clean up a drag-and-drop operation.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.DragEventArgs"></xref> that provides data for the event.
Receives a call when a drag-and-drop object is dropped onto the control designer view.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.DragEventArgs"></xref> that provides data for the event.
Receives a call when a drag-and-drop operation enters the control designer view.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.DragEventArgs"></xref> that provides data for the event.
Receives a call when a drag-and-drop operation leaves the control designer view.
An <xref href="System.EventArgs"></xref> that provides data for the event.
Receives a call when a drag-and-drop object is dragged over the control designer view.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.DragEventArgs"></xref> that provides data for the event.
Receives a call when a drag-and-drop operation is in progress to provide visual cues based on the location of the mouse while a drag operation is in progress.
The designer host calls this method when an OLE drag event occurs.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.GiveFeedbackEventArgs"></xref> that provides data for the event.
Receives a call in response to the left mouse button being pressed and held while over the component.
This method is called at the start of a drag-and-drop operation.

You can pass a point in screen coordinates to the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.PointToClient%2A> method of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control> class to obtain the coordinates of the point relative to the upper-left corner of the control.
The x position of the mouse in screen coordinates.
The y position of the mouse in screen coordinates.
Receives a call at the end of a drag-and-drop operation to complete or cancel the operation.
`true` to cancel the drag; `false` to commit it.
Receives a call for each movement of the mouse during a drag-and-drop operation.

You can pass a point in screen coordinates to the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.PointToClient%2A> method of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control> class to obtain the coordinates of the point relative to the upper-left corner of the control.
The x position of the mouse in screen coordinates.
The y position of the mouse in screen coordinates.
Receives a call when the mouse first enters the control.
Receives a call after the mouse hovers over the control.
Receives a call when the mouse first enters the control.
Receives a call when the control that the designer is managing has painted its surface so the designer can paint any additional adornments on top of the control.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs"></xref> the designer can use to draw on the control.
Called when the designer is intialized.
Receives a call each time the cursor needs to be set.
This method handles redirection and handling of the set cursor event.
If the toolbox service has a tool selected, this method will allow the toolbox service to set the cursor.
If the selection UI service has a locked selection, or if there is no location property on the control, the default arrow cursor will be set.
If a user is dragging a component, the crosshair cursor will be set.
Otherwise, a four headed arrow cursor will be set to indicate that the component can be clicked and moved.
Gets the parent component for the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.ControlDesigner"></xref>.
The default implementation simply checks to see if the component being designed is a control and if it is, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.ControlDesigner.ParentComponent%2A> returns its parent.
The parent component for the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.ControlDesigner"></xref>; otherwise, `null` if there is no parent component.
Gets a value indicating whether the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.ControlDesigner"></xref> will allow snapline alignment during a drag operation.

`true` if the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.ControlDesigner"></xref> will allow snapline alignment during a drag operation when the primary drag control is over this designer; otherwise, `false`.
Adjusts the set of properties the component exposes through a <xref href="System.ComponentModel.TypeDescriptor"></xref>.
This <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.IDesignerFilter> interface method override adds a set of properties to this designer's component at design time.
This method adds the following browsable properties: `Visible`, `Enabled`, `ContextMenu`, `AllowDrop`, `Location`, `Name`, `Controls`, and `Locked`.
An <xref href="System.Collections.IDictionary"></xref> containing the properties for the class of the component.
Gets the selection rules that indicate the movement capabilities of a component.
If no designer provides rules for a component, the component will not get any UI services.
A bitwise combination of <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.SelectionRules"></xref> values.
Gets a list of <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLine"></xref> objects representing significant alignment points for this control.
You can use the offered <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLine> objects to assist in positioning the control on a design surface.
A list of <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Design.Behavior.SnapLine"></xref> objects representing significant alignment points for this control.
Routes messages for the children of the specified control to each control rather than to a parent designer.
The first child <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control"></xref> to process.
This method may recursively call itself for children of the control.
Processes Windows messages and optionally routes them to the control.
This method is called for each message the control would usually receive.
This allows the designer to preprocess messages before optionally routing them to the control.

To send the message to the control’s <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.WndProc%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method, call <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.ControlDesigner.WndProc%2A> on the control's designer.
The designer filters messages, so some messages will not be sent to the control.
For example, mouse messages are intercepted by the designer.
If this is not the behavior you want, call <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Design.ControlDesigner.DefWndProc%2A> instead.
Pass `m` as a parameter.
Optionally, you can alter or create a new <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Message?displayProperty=fullName> to pass to the control's method.
The following table shows the flow of messages.
Without a designer
With a designer
USER32
USER32
USER32
USER32
The designer intercepts messages by replacing the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.WindowTarget%2A?displayProperty=fullName> property on the control.
Usually, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.WindowTarget%2A> points to the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.NativeWindow> contained within the control.
During design time, the designer replaces this with its own window target, and caches the original value.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Message"></xref> to process.
